full_conversation: Therapist: Welcome, Carlos. Let's begin our imaginal exposure exercise. Remember, I'll ask for your SUDS rating every few minutes. Are you ready?
Client: Yes, I think so. I'm feeling a bit nervous, but I'll do my best.
Therapist: That's understandable. Let's start. Close your eyes and recall the memory of police brutality you witnessed.
Client: Okay... I'm at the park. It's a sunny day, but something feels off. I see a group of officers approaching a young man. He looks scared...
Therapist: Good. What's your SUDS level right now?
Client: Um, I'd say about a 4 out of 10.
Therapist: Alright. Continue describing what you see.
Client: The officers are surrounding him now. One of them is yelling, but I can't make out the words. The young man is putting his hands up, trembling. I feel my heart racing...
Therapist: Stay with that feeling. What happens next?
Client: Suddenly, one officer tackles him to the ground. It's so violent... I hear the man cry out in pain. My stomach is churning now.
Therapist: What's your SUDS level?
Client: It's... it's gone up to a 7. I feel sick.
Therapist: You're doing well. Keep going.
Client: The other officers join in. They're... they're hitting him with batons. I can hear the thud of each blow. I want to look away, but I can't. My hands are shaking...
Therapist: How are you feeling right now?
Client: Helpless. Angry. Scared. I should've done something, but I just stood there frozen.
Therapist: That's a normal reaction. What's your SUDS now?
Client: It's an 8. I can barely breathe...
Therapist: Take a deep breath. You're safe here.
Client: I'm trying... The young man is crying out for help. Blood is trickling down his face. I feel like I'm going to throw up...
Therapist: Stay with it. What else do you notice?
Client: People around me are shouting, some are filming. The officers look... almost gleeful. It's horrifying. My legs feel weak...
Therapist: SUDS level?
Client: It's... it's a 9 now. I can't... I can't do this...
Therapist: You can. You're doing great. Keep breathing.
Client: The man goes limp. They're still hitting him. I hear sirens... more police arriving. I'm panicking... I need to get out of here...
Therapist: You're safe here, Carlos. What's happening now?
Client: I'm... I'm running away. I can't bear to watch anymore. I feel so ashamed...
Therapist: It's okay. How's your SUDS level?
Client: It's still at 9. I feel like I'm there again...
Therapist: Take another deep breath. You're here with me, not there.
Client: Okay... I'm trying. My heart is pounding so hard...
Therapist: That's normal. What are you aware of now?
Client: I'm... I'm back home. Shaking. I can't get the images out of my head. I feel so guilty...
Therapist: SUDS level?
Client: It's... dropping a bit. Maybe an 8 now.
Therapist: Good. You're doing well. Keep describing what you're experiencing.
Client: I'm sitting on my couch, trying to calm down. But every time I close my eyes, I see that man's face... hear his screams...
Therapist: Stay with those sensations. What else?
Client: I feel... numb. Like I've witnessed something I can't process. My hands are still trembling...
Therapist: How's your SUDS now?
Client: It's down to a 7. I'm starting to feel more present...
Therapist: That's good. You're doing great, Carlos.
Client: Thank you... I'm exhausted. But I also feel... I don't know, maybe a little relieved to have talked about it?
Therapist: That's a common feeling. How are you doing now?
Client: I'm... okay. My SUDS is probably around a 5 now. I feel drained, but... lighter somehow.
Therapist: You've done excellent work today. Let's start wrapping up...
